    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fonboard-azure.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fonboard-azure.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,140 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Onboard a Microsoft Azure subscription in Permissions Management\n-description: How to a Microsoft Azure subscription on Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# Onboard a Microsoft Azure subscription\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-This article describes how to onboard a Microsoft Azure subscription or subscriptions on Permissions Management. Onboarding a subscription creates a new authorization system to represent the Azure subscription in Permissions Management.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> You must be a [Permissions Management Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#permissions-management-administrator) to perform the tasks in this article.\n-\n-## Explanation\n-\n-The Permissions Management service is built on Azure, and given you're onboarding your Azure subscriptions to be monitored and managed, setup is simple with few moving parts to configure. Below is what is required to configure onboarding:\n-\n-* When your tenant is onboarded, an application is created in the tenant.\n-* This app requires 'reader' permissions on the subscriptions\n-* For controller functionality, the app requires 'User Access Administrator' to create and implement right-size roles\n-\n-## Prerequisites\n-\n-To add Permissions Management to your Microsoft Entra tenant:\n-- You must have a Microsoft Entra user account and an Azure command-line interface (Azure CLI) on your system, or an Azure subscription. If you don't already have one, [create a free account](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/purchase-options/azure-account?cid=msft_learn).\n-- You must have **Microsoft.Authorization/roleAssignments/write** permission at the subscription or management group scope to perform these tasks. If you don't have this permission, you can ask someone who has this permission to perform these tasks for you.\n-\n-## How to onboard an Azure subscription\n-\n-1. If the **Data Collectors** dashboard isn't displayed when Permissions Management launches:\n-\n-    - In the Permissions Management home page, select **Settings** (the gear icon, top right), and then select the **Data Collectors** subtab.\n-\n-1. On the **Data Collectors** dashboard, select **Azure**, and then select **Create Configuration**.\n-\n-### 1. Add Azure subscription details\n-\n-Choose from three options to manage Azure subscriptions. \n-\n-#### Option 1: Automatically manage \n-\n-This option lets subscriptions be automatically detected and monitored without further work required. A key benefit of automatic management is that any current or future subscriptions found are onboarded automatically. The steps to detect a list of subscriptions and onboard for collection are as follows:  \n-\n-- Firstly, grant Reader role to Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management application at management group or subscription scope. To do this:  \n-\n-1. In the EPM portal, left-click the cog on the top right-hand side.  \n-1. Go to data collectors tab \n-1. Ensure **Azure** is selected.\n-1. Click **Create Configuration.**\n-1. For onboarding mode, select **Automatically Manage.**\n-\n-    > [!NOTE]\n-    > The steps listed on the screen outline how to create the role assignment for the Cloud Infrastructure Entitlements Management application. This is performed manually in the Microsoft Entra ID console, or programmatically with PowerShell or the Azure CLI.\n-\n-- Once complete, Click **Verify Now & Save.**\n-\n-To view status of onboarding after saving the configuration: \n-\n-1. Collectors are now listed and change through status types. For each collector listed with a status of **Collected Inventory,** click on that status to view further information. \n-1. You can then view subscriptions on the In Progress page.\n-\n-#### Option 2: Enter authorization systems \n-\n-You have the ability to specify only certain subscriptions to manage and monitor with Permissions Management (up to 100 per collector). Follow the steps below to configure these subscriptions to be monitored: \n-\n-1. For each subscription you wish to manage, ensure that the Reader role has been granted to Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management application for the subscription. \n-1. In the EPM portal, click the cog on the top right-hand side. \n-1. Go to data collectors tab \n-1. Ensure 'Azure' is selected\n-1. Click Create Configuration \n-1. Select Enter Authorization Systems \n-1. Under the Subscription IDs section, enter a desired subscription ID into the input box. Click the + up to nine extra times, putting a single subscription ID into each respective input box. \n-1. Once you have input all of the desired subscriptions, click next \n-1. Click Verify Now & Save \n-1. Once the access to read and collect data is verified, collection will begin. \n-\n-To view status of onboarding after saving the configuration: \n-\n-1. Go to the **Data Collectors** tab.  \n-1. Click on the status of the data collector.  \n-1. View subscriptions on the In Progress page.\n-\n-#### Option 3: Select authorization systems \n-\n-This option detects all subscriptions that are accessible by the Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management application.  \n-\n-- Firstly, grant Reader role to Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management application at management group or subscription scope.  \n-\n-1. In the Permissions Management portal, click the cog on the top right-hand side.  \n-1. Go to the **Data Collectors** tab.\n-1. Ensure **Azure** is selected.\n-1. Click **Create Configuration.** \n-1. For onboarding mode, select **Automatically Manage.** \n-\n-    > [!NOTE]\n-    > The steps listed on the screen outline how to create the role assignment for the Cloud Infrastructure Entitlements Management application. You can do this manually in the Microsoft Entra ID console, or programmatically with PowerShell or the Azure CLI.\n-\n-- Once complete, Click **Verify Now & Save.** \n-\n-To view status of onboarding after saving the configuration: \n-\n-1. Go to newly create Data Collector row under Azure data collectors. \n-1. Click on Status column when the row has **Pending** status \n-1. To onboard and start collection, choose specific ones subscriptions from the detected list and consent for collection.\n-\n-### 2. Review and save.\n-\n-1. In **Permissions Management Onboarding  Summary** page, review the information you've added, and then select **Verify Now & Save**.\n-\n-    The following message appears: **Successfully Created Configuration.**\n-\n-    On the **Data Collectors** tab, the **Recently Uploaded On** column displays **Collecting**. The **Recently Transformed On** column displays **Processing.**\n-\n-    The status column in your Permissions Management UI shows you which step of data collection you're at:  \n- \n-    - **Pending**: Permissions Management has not started detecting or onboarding yet. \n-    - **Discovering**: Permissions Management is detecting the authorization systems. \n-    - **In progress**: Permissions Management has finished detecting the authorization systems and is onboarding. \n-    - **Onboarded**: Data collection is complete, and all detected authorization systems are onboarded to Permissions Management. \n-\n-### 3. View the data.\n-\n-1. To view the data, select the **Authorization Systems** tab.\n-\n-    The **Status** column in the table displays **Collecting Data.**\n-\n-    The data collection process takes some time and occurs in approximately 4-5 hour intervals in most cases. The time frame depends on the size of the authorization system you have and how much data is available for collection.\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- For information on how to start viewing information about your authorization system in Permissions Management, see [View key statistics and data about your authorization system](ui-dashboard.md)."
  },
  {
    "sha": "ce636629cac2625714c98f2c3e6b8b98ad10bcb5",
    "filename": "docs/permissions-management/onboard-enable-controller-after-onboarding.md",

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fonboard-enable-controller-after-onboarding.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fonboard-enable-controller-after-onboarding.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,108 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Enable or disable the controller in Permissions Management after onboarding is complete\n-description: How to enable or disable the controller in Permissions Management after onboarding is complete.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# Enable or disable the controller after onboarding is complete\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-With the controller, you can decide what level of access to grant in Permissions Management.\n-\n-* Enable to grant read and write access to your environments. You can right-size permissions and remediate through Permissions Management.\n-    \n-* Disable to grant read-only access to your environments.\n-\n-\n-This article describes how to enable the controller in Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud Platform (GCP) after onboarding is complete.\n-\n-\n-This article also describes how to disable the controller in Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Once you enable the controller in AWS, you can't disable it.\n-\n-\n-## Enable the controller in AWS\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n->  You can enable the controller in AWS if you disabled it during onboarding. Once you enable the controller in AWS, you cant disable it.\n-\n-1. In a separate browser window, sign in to the AWS console of the member account.\n-1. Go to the Permissions Management home page, select **Settings** (the gear icon), then select the **Data Collectors** subtab.\n-1. On the **Data Collectors** dashboard, select **AWS**, then select **Create Configuration**.\n-1. On the **Permissions Management Onboarding - AWS Member Account Details** page, select **Launch Template**.\n-\n-    The **AWS CloudFormation create stack** page opens, displaying the template.\n-1. In the **CloudTrailBucketName** box, enter a name.\n-\n-    You can copy and paste the **CloudTrailBucketName** name from the **Trails** page in AWS.\n-\n-    > [!NOTE]\n-    >  A *cloud bucket* collects all the activity in a single account that Permissions Management monitors. Enter the name of a cloud bucket here to provide Permissions Management with the access required to collect activity data.\n-\n-1. In the **EnableController** box, from the drop-down list, select **True** to provide Permissions Management with read and write access so that any remediation you want to do from the Permissions Management platform can be done automatically.\n-\n-1. Scroll to the bottom of the page, and in the **Capabilities** box and select **I acknowledge that AWS CloudFormation might create IAM resources with custom names**. Then select **Create stack**.\n-\n-    This AWS CloudFormation stack creates a collection role in the member account with necessary permissions (policies) for data collection. A trust policy is set on this role to allow the OIDC role created in your AWS OIDC account to access it. These entities are listed in the **Resources** tab of your CloudFormation stack.\n-\n-1. Return to Permissions Management, and on the Permissions Management **Onboarding - AWS Member Account Details** page, select **Next**.\n-1. On **Permissions Management Onboarding  Summary** page, review the information you've added, then select **Verify Now & Save**.\n-\n-    The following message appears: **Successfully created configuration.**\n-\n-## Enable or disable the controller in Azure\n-\n-You can enable or disable the controller in Azure at the Subscription level of your Management Group(s).  \n-\n-1. From the Azure [**Home**](https://portal.azure.com) page, select **Management groups**.\n-1. Locate the group for which you want to enable or disable the controller, then select the arrow to expand the group menu and view your subscriptions. Alternatively, you can select the **Total Subscriptions** number listed for your group.\n-1. Select the subscription for which you want to enable or disable the controller, then click **Access control (IAM)** in the navigation menu.\n-1. In the **Check access** section, in the **Find** box, enter **Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management**.\n-\n-    The **Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management assignments** page appears, displaying the roles assigned to you.\n-\n-    - If you have read-only permission, the **Role** column displays **Reader**.\n-    - If you have administrative permission, the **Role** column displays **User Access Administrator**.\n-\n-1. To add the administrative role assignment, return to the **Access control (IAM)** page, then select **Add role assignment**.\n-1. Add or remove the role assignment for Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management.\n-\n-1. Go to the Permissions Management home page, select **Settings** (the gear icon), then select the **Data Collectors** subtab.\n-1. On the **Data Collectors** dashboard, select **Azure**, then select **Create Configuration**.\n-1. On the **Permissions Management Onboarding - Azure Subscription Details** page, enter the **Subscription ID**, then select **Next**.\n-1. On **Permissions Management Onboarding  Summary** page, review the controller permissions, then select **Verify Now & Save**.\n-\n-    The following message appears: **Successfully Created Configuration.**\n-\n-\n-## Enable or disable the controller in GCP\n-\n-1. Execute the **gcloud auth login**.\n-1. Follow the instructions displayed on the screen to authorize access to your Google account.\n-1. Execute the ``sh mciem-workload-identity-pool.sh`` to create the workload identity pool, provider, and service account.\n-1. Execute the [``sh mciem-member-projects.sh``](https://github.com/cloudknox/mciem-onboard-gcp/blob/master/mciem-member-projects.sh) to give Permissions Management permissions to access each of the member projects.\n-\n-    - If you want to manage permissions through Permissions Management, select **Y** to **Enable controller**.\n-    - If you want to onboard your projects in read-only mode, select **N** to **Disable controller**.\n-\n-1. Optionally, execute ``mciem-enable-gcp-api.sh`` to enable all recommended GCP APIs.\n-\n-1. Go to the Permissions Management home page, select **Settings** (the gear icon), then select the **Data Collectors** subtab.\n-1. On the **Data Collectors** dashboard, select **GCP**, and then select **Create Configuration**.\n-1. On the **Permissions Management Onboarding - Microsoft Entra OIDC App Creation** page, select **Next**.\n-1. On the **Permissions Management Onboarding - GCP OIDC Account Details & IDP Access** page, enter the **OIDC Project Number** and **OIDC Project ID**, and then select **Next**.\n-1. On the **Permissions Management Onboarding - GCP Project IDs** page, enter the **Project IDs**, then select **Next**.\n-1. On the **Permissions Management Onboarding  Summary** page, review the information you've added, then select **Verify Now & Save**.\n-\n-    The following message appears: **Successfully Created Configuration.**\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- For information on how to add an account/subscription/project after onboarding is complete, see [Add an account/subscription/project after onboarding is complete](onboard-add-account-after-onboarding.md)."
  },

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fonboard-enable-tenant.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fonboard-enable-tenant.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,72 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Enable Microsoft Entra Permissions Management in your organization\n-description: How to enable Microsoft Entra Permissions Management in your organization.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 05/02/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n-ms.custom: sfi-ga-nochange\n----\n-\n-# Enable Microsoft Entra Permissions Management in your organization\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-This article describes how to enable Microsoft Entra Permissions Management in your organization. Once you've enabled Permissions Management, you can connect it to your Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud Platform (GCP) platforms.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> To complete this task, you must have at least [*Billing Administrator*](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2248574) permissions. You can't enable Permissions Management as a user from another tenant who has signed in via B2B or via Azure Lighthouse.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/onboard-enable-tenant/dashboard.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Microsoft Entra Permissions Management dashboard.\" lightbox=\"media/onboard-enable-tenant/dashboard.png\":::\n-\n-## Prerequisites\n-\n-To enable Permissions Management in your organization:\n-\n-- You must have a Microsoft Entra tenant. If you don't already have one, [create a free account](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/purchase-options/azure-account?cid=msft_learn).\n-- You must be eligible for or have an active assignment to the *Permissions Management Administrator* role as a user in that tenant.\n-\n-<a name='how-to-enable-permissions-management-on-your-azure-ad-tenant'></a>\n-\n-## How to enable Permissions Management on your Microsoft Entra tenant\n-\n-1. In your browser:\n-    1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com/#home) as at least a [Billing Administrator](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2254515).\n-    1. If needed, activate the *Permissions Management Administrator* role in your Microsoft Entra tenant.\n-    1. Browse to **Entra ID**, then select **Go to Microsoft Entra ID**.\n-    1. In the Entra ID portal, select **Microsoft Entra Permissions Management**, then select the link to purchase a license or begin a trial.\n-\n-\n-## Activate a free trial or paid license \n-There are two ways to activate a trial or a full product license. \n-- The first way is to go to the [Microsoft 365 admin center](https://admin.microsoft.com).\n-    - Sign in as a *Global Administrator* for your tenant.\n-    - Go to Setup and sign up for a Microsoft Entra Permissions Management trial. \n-    - For self-service, Go to the [Microsoft 365 portal](https://aka.ms/TryPermissionsManagement) to sign up for a 45-day free trial or to purchase licenses. \n-- The second way is through Volume Licensing or Enterprise agreements. \n-    - If your organization falls under a volume license or enterprise agreement scenario, contact your Microsoft representative.\n-\n-Permissions Management launches with the **Data Collectors** dashboard.\n-\n-## Configure data collection settings\n-\n-Use the **Data Collectors** dashboard in Permissions Management to configure data collection settings for your authorization system.\n-\n-1. If the **Data Collectors** dashboard isn't displayed when Permissions Management launches:\n-\n-    - In the Permissions Management home page, select **Settings** (the gear icon), then select the **Data Collectors** subtab.\n-\n-1. Select the authorization system you want: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-\n-1. For information on how to onboard an AWS account, Azure subscription, or GCP project into Permissions Management, select one of the following articles and follow the instructions:\n-\n-    - [Onboard an AWS account](onboard-aws.md)\n-    - [Onboard an Azure subscription](onboard-azure.md)\n-    - [Onboard a GCP project](onboard-gcp.md)\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- For an overview of Permissions Management, see [What's Microsoft Entra Permissions Management?](overview.md)"
  },

    "sha": "ceb9e7be7615e27e1af783dd4c27d18d3cd750c4",

    "patch": "@@ -1,149 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title:  Onboard a Google Cloud Platform (GCP) project in Permissions Management\n-description: How to onboard a Google Cloud Platform (GCP) project on Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# Onboard a Google Cloud Platform (GCP) project\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-This article describes how to onboard a Google Cloud Platform (GCP) project in Microsoft Entra Permissions Management.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> You must be a [Permissions Management Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#permissions-management-administrator) to perform the tasks in this article.\n-\n-## Explanation\n-\n-For GCP, Permissions Management is scoped to a *GCP project*. A GCP project is a logical collection of your resources in GCP, like a subscription in Azure, but with further configurations you can perform such as application registrations and OIDC configurations.\n-\n-<!-- Diagram from Gargi-->\n-\n-There are several moving parts across GCP and Azure, which should be configured before onboarding.\n-\n-* A Microsoft Entra OIDC App\n-* A Workload Identity in GCP\n-* OAuth2 confidential client grants utilized\n-* A GCP service account with permissions to collect\n-\n-\n-## Onboard a GCP project\n-\n-1. If the **Data Collectors** dashboard isn't displayed when Permissions Management launches:\n-\n-    - In the Permissions Management home page, select **Settings** (the gear icon), and then select the **Data Collectors** subtab.\n-\n-1. On the **Data Collectors** tab, select **GCP**, then select **Create Configuration**.\n-\n-<a name='1-create-an-azure-ad-oidc-app'></a>\n-\n-### 1. Create a Microsoft Entra OIDC app.\n-\n-1. On the **Permissions Management Onboarding - Microsoft Entra OIDC App Creation** page, enter the **OIDC Azure App Name**.\n-\n-    This app is used to set up an OpenID Connect (OIDC) connection to your GCP project. OIDC is an interoperable authentication protocol based on the OAuth 2.0 family of specifications. The scripts generated create the app of this specified name in your Microsoft Entra tenant with the right configuration.\n-\n-1. To create the app registration, copy the script and run it in your command-line app.\n-\n-    > [!NOTE]\n-    > 1. To confirm the app was created, open **App registrations** in Azure and, on the **All applications** tab, locate your app.\n-    > 1. Select the app name to open the **Expose an API** page. The **Application ID URI** displayed in the **Overview** page is the *audience value* used while making an OIDC connection with your GCP account.\n-    > 1. Return to the Permissions Management window, and in the **Permissions Management Onboarding - Microsoft Entra OIDC App Creation**, select **Next**.\n-\n-### 2. Set up a GCP OIDC project.\n-1. In the **Permissions Management Onboarding - GCP OIDC Account Details & IDP Access** page, enter the **OIDC Project Number** and **OIDC Project ID** of the GCP project in which the OIDC provider and pool is created. You can change the role name to your requirements.\n-\n-    > [!NOTE]\n-    > You can find the **Project number** and **Project ID** of your GCP project on the GCP **Dashboard** page of your project in the **Project info** panel.\n-\n-1. You can change the **OIDC Workload Identity Pool Id**, **OIDC Workload Identity Pool Provider Id** and **OIDC Service Account Name** to meet your requirements.\n-\n-    Optionally, specify **G-Suite IDP Secret Name** and **G-Suite IDP User Email** to enable G-Suite integration.\n-\n-\n-1. You can either download and run the script at this point or you can do it in the Google Cloud Shell.\n-\n-1. Select **Next** after successfully running the setup script. \n-\n-Choose from three options to manage GCP projects. \n-\n-#### Option 1: Automatically manage \n-\n-The automatically manage option allows you to automatically detect and monitor projects without extra configuration. Steps to detect a list of projects and onboard for collection:  \n-\n-1. Grant **Viewer** and **Security Reviewer** roles to a service account created in the previous step at a project, folder or organization level. \n-\n-To enable Controller mode **On** for any projects, add these roles to the specific projects:\n-- Role Administrators\n-- Security Admin \n-\n-The required commands to run in Google Cloud Shell are listed in the Manage Authorization screen for each scope of a project, folder or organization. This is also configured in the GCP console.\n-\n-3. Select **Next**.\n-\n-#### Option 2: Enter authorization systems \n-You have the ability to specify only certain GCP member projects to manage and monitor with Permissions Management (up to 100 per collector). Follow the steps to configure these GCP member projects to be monitored: \n-1. In the **Permissions Management Onboarding - GCP Project Ids** page, enter the **Project IDs**.\n-\n-    You can enter up to comma separated 100 GCP project IDs. \n-\n-2. You can choose to download and run the script at this point, or you can do it via Google Cloud Shell.\n-    \n-    To enable controller mode 'On' for any projects, add these roles to the specific projects:\n-    - Role Administrators\n-    - Security Admin \n-\n-3. Select **Next**.\n-\n-#### Option 3: Select authorization systems \n-\n-This option detects all projects accessible by the Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management application.  \n-\n-1. Grant **Viewer** and **Security Reviewer** roles to a service account created in the previous step at a project, folder or organization level. \n-\n-To enable Controller mode **On** for any projects, add these roles to the specific projects:\n-- Role Administrators\n-- Security Admin \n-\n-The required commands to run in Google Cloud Shell are listed in the Manage Authorization screen for each scope of a project, folder or organization. This is also configured in the GCP console.\n-\n-3. Select **Next**.\n-\n-\n-### 3. Review and save.\n-\n-1. In the **Permissions Management Onboarding  Summary** page, review the information you've added, and then select **Verify Now & Save**.\n-\n-    The following message appears: **Successfully Created Configuration**.\n-\n-    On the **Data Collectors** tab, the **Recently Uploaded On** column displays **Collecting**. The **Recently Transformed On** column displays **Processing.**\n-    \n-    The status column in your Permissions Management UI shows you which step of data collection you're at:  \n- \n-    - **Pending**: Permissions Management has not started detecting or onboarding yet. \n-    - **Discovering**: Permissions Management is detecting the authorization systems. \n-    - **In progress**: Permissions Management has finished detecting the authorization systems and is onboarding. \n-    - **Onboarded**: Data collection is complete, and all detected authorization systems are onboarded to Permissions Management. \n-\n-### 4. View the data.\n-\n-1. To view the data, select the **Authorization Systems** tab.\n-\n-    The **Status** column in the table displays **Collecting Data.**\n-\n-    The data collection process takes some time and occurs in approximately 4-5 hour intervals in most cases. The time frame depends on the size of the authorization system you have and how much data is available for collection.\n-\n-\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- To enable or disable the controller after onboarding is complete, see [Enable or disable the controller](onboard-enable-controller-after-onboarding.md).\n-- To add an account/subscription/project after onboarding is complete, see [Add an account/subscription/project after onboarding is complete](onboard-add-account-after-onboarding.md)."
  },

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Foverview.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,74 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: What's Microsoft Entra Permissions Management?\n-description: An introduction to Microsoft Entra Permissions Management.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: overview\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# What's Microsoft Entra Permissions Management\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-Microsoft Entra Permissions Management is a cloud infrastructure entitlement management (CIEM) solution that provides comprehensive visibility into permissions assigned to all identities. For example, over-privileged workload and user identities, actions, and resources across multicloud infrastructures in Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services (AWS), and Google Cloud Platform (GCP).\n-\n-Permissions Management  detects, automatically right-sizes, and continuously monitors unused and excessive permissions.\n-\n-Organizations have to consider permissions management as a central piece of their Zero Trust security to implement least privilege access across their entire infrastructure:\n-\n-- Organizations are increasingly adopting multicloud strategy and are struggling with the lack of visibility and the increasing complexity of managing access permissions.\n-- With the growth of identities and cloud services, the number of high-risk cloud permissions is exploding, expanding the attack surface for organizations.\n-- IT security teams are under increased pressure to ensure access to their expanding cloud estate is secure and compliant.\n-- The inconsistency of cloud providers' native access management models makes it even more complex for Security and Identity to manage permissions and enforce least privilege access policies across their entire environment.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/overview/key-use-cases.png\" alt-text=\"Diagram of Microsoft Entra Permissions Management use cases.\" lightbox=\"media/overview/key-use-cases.png\":::\n-\n-## Key use cases\n-\n-Permissions Management allows customers to address three key use cases: *discover*, *remediate*, and *monitor*.\n-\n-Permissions Management is designed in such a way that we recommended you 'step-through' each of the below phases in order to gain insights into permissions across the organization. This is because you generally can't take action on what has not been discovered, likewise you can't continually evaluate what has not been remediated.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/overview/discover-remediate-monitor.png\" alt-text=\"Permissions Management use case diagram showing the discover, remediate, and monitor phases.\":::\n-\n-### Discover\n-\n-Customers can assess permission risks by evaluating the gap between permissions granted and permissions used.\n-\n-- Cross-cloud permissions discovery: Granular and normalized metrics for key cloud platforms: AWS, Azure, and GCP.\n-- Permission Creep Index (PCI): An aggregated metric that periodically evaluates the level of risk associated with the number of unused or excessive permissions across your identities and resources. It measures how much damage identities can cause based on the permissions they have.\n-- Permission usage analytics: Multi-dimensional view of permissions risk for all identities, actions, and resources.\n-\n-### Remediate\n-\n-Customers can right-size permissions based on usage, grant new permissions on-demand, and automate just-in-time access for cloud resources.\n-\n-- Automated deletion of permissions unused for the past 90 days.\n-- Permissions on-demand: Grant identities permissions on-demand for a time-limited period or an as-needed basis.\n-\n-\n-### Monitor\n-\n-Customers can detect anomalous activities with machine learning-powered (ML-powered) alerts and generate detailed forensic reports.\n-\n-- ML-powered anomaly detections.\n-- Context-rich forensic reports around identities, actions, and resources to support rapid investigation and remediation.\n-\n-Permissions Management deepens Zero Trust security strategies by augmenting the least privilege access principle, allowing customers to:\n-\n-- Get comprehensive visibility: Discover which identity is doing what, where, and when.\n-- Automate least privilege access: Use access analytics to ensure identities have the right permissions, at the right time.\n-- Unify access policies across infrastructure as a service (IaaS) platforms: Implement consistent security policies across your cloud infrastructure.\n-\n-Once your organization has explored and implemented the discover, remediation and monitor phases, you've established one of the core pillars of a modern zero-trust security strategy.\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- Deepen your learning with [Introduction to Microsoft Entra Permissions Management](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2240016) learn module. \n-- Sign up for a [45-day free trial](https://aka.ms/TryPermissionsManagement) of Permissions Management.\n-- For a list of frequently asked questions (FAQs) about Permissions Management, see [FAQs](faqs.md)."
  },
  {

    "patch": "@@ -1,53 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title:  Microsoft Entra Permissions Management partners\n-description: View current Microsoft Entra Permissions Management partners and their websites.\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: reference\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# Microsoft Entra Permissions Management partners\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-Microsoft verified partners can help you onboard Microsoft Entra Permissions Management (Permissions Management) and run a risk assessment across your entire multicloud environment.\n-\n-## Benefits of working with Microsoft verified partners\n-\n-* **Product Expertise**\n-\n-    Our partners help you navigate Permissions Management, letting you in on best practices and guidance to enhance your security strategy.\n-\n-* **Risk Assessment**\n-\n-    Partners guide you through the Microsoft Entra Permissions Management risk assessment and help you identify top permission risks across your multicloud infrastructure.\n-\n-* **Onboarding and Deployment Support**\n-\n-    Partners can guide you through the entire onboarding and deployment process for Permissions Management across AWS, Azure, and GCP.\n-\n-\n-## Partner list\n-\n-Select a partner from the list provided to begin your Permissions Management risk assessment. Additionally, Microsoft provides a [full list of security partners](https://www.microsoft.com/security/business/find-a-partner) that can help secure your organization.\n-\n-If you're a partner and would like to be considered for the Microsoft Entra Permissions Management partner list, submit a     "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fpermissions-management-for-defender-for-cloud.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fpermissions-management-for-defender-for-cloud.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,41 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Microsoft Entra Permissions Management integrates with Microsoft Defender for Cloud\n-description: Learn how Microsoft Entra Permissions Management helps strengthen security in cloud environments as an enhancement for Defender for Cloud\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-\n-ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# Microsoft Entra Permissions Management integration with Microsoft Defender for Cloud\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management (CIEM) is a security model that helps organizations manage and control user access and entitlements in their cloud infrastructure. CIEM is a critical component of a Cloud Native Application Protection Platform (CNAPP) solution providing visibility into who has access to what resources and ensuring access rights align with the principle of least privilege (PoLP), where users have the minimum levels of access necessary to perform their tasks.  \n- \n-Microsoft delivers both CNAPP and CIEM solutions with Microsoft Defender for Cloud (CNAPP) and Microsoft Entra Permissions Management (CIEM). While both Defender for Cloud and Permissions Management help secure customers cloud environments, they're two distinct security solutions that address different aspects of cloud security. Permissions Management focuses on managing and enforcing fine-grained access controls, permissions, and entitlements for identities across multicloud infrastructures. Defender for Cloud focuses on securing cloud-native applications such as containers, microservices, and serverless applications through visibility into application behavior and security posture.  \n-\n-## How Permissions Management works with Defender for Cloud\n-\n-Permissions Management capabilities are available to integrate into the Defender for Cloud CSPM plan. Adding the capabilities of Permissions Management to Defender for Cloud strengthens the prevention of security breaches that might occur due to excessive permissions or misconfigurations in the cloud environment. By continuously monitoring and managing cloud entitlements, Permissions Management helps to reduce the attack surface, detect potential threats, and maintain compliance with regulatory standards. These added features make Permissions Management an essential tool to integrate into the capabilities of Defender for Cloud for securing cloud-native applications and protecting sensitive data in the cloud. \n-\n-\n-## Permissions Management and Defender for Cloud capabilities\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/permissions-management-for-defender-for-cloud/permissions-management-defender-for-cloud-comparison.png\" alt-text=\"A table showing the difference in capabilities of Permissions Management and Defender for Cloud.\" lightbox=\"media/permissions-management-for-defender-for-cloud/permissions-management-defender-for-cloud-comparison.png\":::\n-\n-\n-\n-## Common use cases and scenarios\n-\n-With the added capabilities of Permissions Management, you can track permissions analytics, unused permissions for active identities, and over-permissioned identities then act to mitigate them to support the best practice of least privilege in Defender for Cloud. \n-\n-\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- For instructions on how to enable Permissions Management in your Defender for Cloud environment, see [Enable Permissions Management in Microsoft Defender for Cloud](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2252561)."
  },

    "sha": "f9609afd3b709a628c08f8130560ed9f69fed9e7",

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fpermissions-management-quickstart-guide.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fpermissions-management-quickstart-guide.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,196 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Microsoft Entra Permissions Management Quickstart Guide\n-description: Quickstart guide - How to quickly onboard your Microsoft Entra Permissions Management product\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management\n-ms.topic: quickstart\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n-ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n-# CustomerIntent: As a security administrator, I want to successfully onboard Permissions Management so that I can enable identity security in my cloud environment as efficiently as possible.'\n----\n-\n-# Quickstart guide to Microsoft Entra Permissions Management \n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-Welcome to the Quickstart Guide for Microsoft Entra Permissions Management. \n-\n-Permissions Management is a Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management (CIEM) solution that provides comprehensive visibility into permissions assigned to all identities. These identities include over-privileged workload and user identities, actions, and resources across multicloud infrastructures in Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services (AWS), and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Permissions Management helps your organization effectively secure and manage cloud permissions by detecting, automatically right-sizing, and continuously monitoring unused and excessive permissions. \n-\n-With this quickstart guide, youll set up your multicloud environment(s), configure data collection, and enable permissions access to ensure your cloud identities are managed and secure.  \n-\n-## Prerequisites \n-\n-Before you begin, you need access to these tools for the onboarding process: \n-\n-- Access to a local BASH shell with the Azure CLI or Azure Cloud Shell using BASH environment (Azure CLI is included). \n-- Access to AWS, Azure, and GCP consoles.\n-- A user must have the [Permissions Management Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#permissions-management-administrator) role assignment to create a new app registration in Microsoft Entra tenant is required for AWS and GCP onboarding. \n-\n-\n-## Step 1: Set-up Permissions Management\n-\n-To enable Permissions Management, you must have a Microsoft Entra tenant (example, Microsoft Entra admin center).  \n-- If you have an Azure account, you automatically have a Microsoft Entra admin center tenant. \n-- If you dont already have one, create a free account at [entra.microsoft.com.](https://entra.microsoft.com)\n-\n-If the above points are met, continue with:\n-\n-[Enable Microsoft Entra Permissions Management in your organization](onboard-enable-tenant.md)\n-\n-Ensure you're a [Permissions Management Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#permissions-management-administrator). Learn more about [Permissions Management roles and permissions](product-roles-permissions.md). \n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/permissions-management-quickstart-guide/entra-id-roles-sync-azure-environment.png\" alt-text=\"A diagram showing where Microsoft Entra intersect with Azure roles in the Microsoft Entra tenant.\" lightbox=\"media/permissions-management-quickstart-guide/entra-id-roles-sync-azure-environment.png\":::\n- \n-## Step 2: Onboard your multicloud environment\n-\n-So far youve,  \n-\n-1. Been assigned the *Permissions Management Administrator* role in your Microsoft Entra admin center tenant. \n-2. Purchased licenses or activated your 45-day free trial for Permissions Management. \n-3. Successfully launched Permissions Management.\n-\n-Now, you're going to learn about the role and settings of the Controller and Data collection modes in Permissions Management.\n-\n-### Set the controller \n-The controller gives you the choice to determine the level of access you grant to users in Permissions Management.  \n-\n-- Enabling the controller during onboarding grants Permissions Management admin access, or read and write access, so users can right-size permissions and remediate directly through Permissions Management (instead of going to the AWS, Azure, or GCP consoles). \n-\n-- Disabling the controller during onboarding, or never enabling it, grants a Permissions Management user read-only access to your environment(s).  \n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> If you don't enable the controller during onboarding, you have the option to enable it after onboarding is complete. To set the controller in Permissions Management after onboarding, see [Enable or disable the controller after onboarding](onboard-enable-controller-after-onboarding.md).\n-> For AWS environments, once you have enabled the controller, you *cannot* disable it. \n-\n-To set the controller settings during onboarding:\n-1. Select **Enable** to give read and write access to Permissions Management.\n-2. Select **Disable** to give read-only access to Permissions Management.\n-\n-### Configure data collection\n-\n-There are three modes to choose from in order to collect data in Permissions Management. \n-\n-- **Automatic (recommended)** \n-Permissions Management automatically discovers, onboards, and monitors all current and future subscriptions. \n-\n-- **Manual** \n-Manually enter individual subscriptions for Permissions Management to discover, onboard, and monitor. You can enter up to 100 subscriptions per data collection.  \n-\n-- **Select** \n-Permissions Management automatically discovers all current subscriptions. Once discovered, you select which subscriptions to onboard and monitor. \n-\n-> [!NOTE] \n-> To use **Automatic** or **Select** modes, the controller must be enabled while configuring data collection. \n-\n-To configure data collection:\n-1. In Permissions Management, go to the **Data Collectors** page.\n-2. Select a cloud environment: **AWS**, **Azure**, or **GCP**.\n-3. Click **Create configuration**.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> The data collection process takes some time and occurs in approximately 4-5 hour intervals in most cases. The time frame depends on the size of the authorization system you have and how much data is available for collection.\n-\n-\n-### Onboard Amazon Web Services (AWS)\n-Since Permissions Management is hosted on Microsoft Entra, there are more steps to take to onboard your AWS environment.  \n-\n-To connect AWS to Permissions Management, you must create a Microsoft Entra application in the Microsoft Entra admin center tenant where Permissions Management is enabled. This Microsoft Entra application is used to set up an OIDC connection to your AWS environment.\n-\n-*OpenID Connect (OIDC) is an interoperable authentication protocol based on the OAuth 2.0 family of specifications.*\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/permissions-management-quickstart-guide/entra-id-tenant-amazon-web-service-connection.png\" alt-text=\"A diagram showing the connection between Microsoft Entra ID and an AWS cloud environment.\" lightbox=\"media/permissions-management-quickstart-guide/entra-id-tenant-amazon-web-service-connection.png\":::\n-\n-\n-### Prerequisites \n-\n-A user must have the [Permissions Management Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#permissions-management-administrator) role assignment to create a new app registration in Microsoft Entra ID. \n-\n-Account IDs and roles for: \n-- AWS OIDC account: An AWS member account designated by you to create and host the OIDC connection through an OIDC IdP\n-- AWS Logging account (optional but recommended) \n-- AWS Management account (optional but recommended)  \n-- AWS member accounts monitored and managed by Permissions Management (for manual mode) \n-\n-To use **Automatic** or **Select** data collection modes, you must connect your AWS Management account.  \n-\n-During this step, you can enable the controller by entering the name of the S3 bucket with AWS CloudTrail activity logs (found on AWS Trails). \n-\n-To onboard your AWS environment and configure data collection, see [Onboard an Amazon Web Services (AWS) account](onboard-aws.md).\n-\n-### Onboard Microsoft Azure\n-When you enabled Permissions Management in the Microsoft Entra tenant, an enterprise application for CIEM was created. To onboard your Azure environment, you grant permissions to this application for Permissions management.\n-\n-1. In the Microsoft Entra tenant where Permissions management is enabled, locate the **Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management (CIEM)** enterprise application.  \n-\n-2. Assign the *Reader* role to the CIEM application to allow Permissions management to read the Microsoft Entra subscriptions in your environment. \n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/permissions-management-quickstart-guide/entra-id-tenant-role-connection-azure-subscriptions.png\" alt-text=\"A diagram showing the connection between the Microsoft Entra role connections to an Azure subscription.\" lightbox=\"media/permissions-management-quickstart-guide/entra-id-tenant-role-connection-azure-subscriptions.png\":::\n-\n-### Prerequisites \n-- A user with ```Microsoft.Authorization/roleAssignments/write``` permissions at the subscription or management group scope to assign roles to the CIEM application.\n-\n-- To use **Automatic** or **Select** data collection modes, you must assign the *Reader* role at the Management group scope. \n-\n-- To enable the controller, you must assign the *User Access Administrator* role to the CIEM application. \n-\n-To onboard your Azure environment and configure data collection, see [Onboard a Microsoft Azure subscription](onboard-azure.md).\n-\n-\n-### Onboard Google Cloud Platform (GCP)\n-Because Permissions Management is hosted on Microsoft Azure, there are additional steps to take to onboard your GCP environment.\n-\n-To connect GCP to Permissions Management, you must create a Microsoft Entra admin center application in the Microsoft Entra tenant where Permissions Management is enabled. This Microsoft Entra admin center application is used to set up an OIDC connection to your GCP environment.   \n-\n-*OpenID Connect (OIDC) is an interoperable authentication protocol based on the OAuth 2.0 family of specifications.* \n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/permissions-management-quickstart-guide/google-cloud-platform-oidc-application.png\" alt-text=\"A diagram showing the connection between the Microsoft Entra OIDC application and a GCP cloud environment.\" lightbox=\"media/permissions-management-quickstart-guide/google-cloud-platform-oidc-application.png\":::\n-\n-### Prerequisites \n-A user with the ability to create a new app registration in Microsoft Entra (needed to facilitate the OIDC connection) is needed for AWS and GCP onboarding. \n- \n-ID details for: \n-- GCP OIDC project: a GCP project designated by you to create and host the OIDC connection through an OIDC IdP. \n-    - Project number and project ID \n-- GCP OIDC Workload identity \n-    - Pool ID, pool provider ID \n-- GCP OIDC service account \n-    - G-suite IdP Secret name and G-suite IdP user email (optional) \n-    - IDs for the GCP projects you wish to onboard (optional, for manual mode)\n-\n-Assign the *Viewer* and *Security Reviewer* roles to the GCP service account at the organization, folder, or project levels to grant Permissions management read access to your GCP environment. \n-\n-During this step, you have the option to **Enable** controller mode by assigning the *Role Administrator* and *Security Administrator* roles to the GCP service account at the organization, folder, or project levels. \n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> The Permissions Management default scope is at the project level. \n-\n-To onboard your GCP environment and configure data collection, see [Onboard a GCP project](onboard-gcp.md).\n-\n-## Summary\n-\n-Congratulations! You have finished configuring data collection for your environment(s), and the data collection process has begun. The data collection process takes some time; approximately 4-5 hours in most cases. The time frame depends on the amount of authorization systems you've onboarded and how much data is available for collection.  \n-\n-The status column in your Permissions Management UI shows you which step of data collection you're at.  \n-\n- \n-- **Pending**: Permissions Management has not started detecting or onboarding yet. \n-- **Discovering**: Permissions Management is detecting the authorization systems. \n-- **In progress**: Permissions Management has finished detecting the authorization systems and is onboarding. \n-- **Onboarded**: Data collection is complete, and all detected authorization systems are onboarded to Permissions Management. \n-\n-> [!NOTE] \n-> While the data collection process continues, you can begin setting up [users and groups in Permissions Management](how-to-add-remove-user-to-group.md). \n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- [Enable or disable the controller after onboarding](onboard-enable-controller-after-onboarding.md)\n-- [Add an account/subscription/project after onboarding is complete](onboard-add-account-after-onboarding.md)\n-- [Create folders to organize your authorization systems](how-to-create-folders.md)\n-\n-References:\n-- [Permissions Management Glossary](multi-cloud-glossary.md)\n-- [Permissions Management FAQs](faqs.md)"
  },

    "sha": "367463e85cc1727071ae285203d1c3230d1edf6c",

    "status": "removed",
    "additions": 0,
    "deletions": 79,
    "changes": 79,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fproduct-account-explorer.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fproduct-account-explorer.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fpermissions-management%2Fproduct-account-explorer.md?ref=446cdc04b6fcc1b18c873488f029e3b613daa30a",
    "patch": "@@ -1,79 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: View roles and identities that can access account information from an external account\n-description: How to view information about identities that can access accounts from an external account in Permissions Management.\n-manager: pmwongera\n-ms.service: entra-permissions-management \n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-author: jenniferf-skc\n-ms.date: 04/01/2025\n-ms.author: jfields\n----\n-\n-# View roles and identities that can access account information from an external account\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Effective April 1, 2025, Microsoft Entra Permissions Management will no longer be available for purchase, and on November 1, 2025, we'll retire and discontinue support of this product. More information can be found [here](https://aka.ms/MEPMretire).\n-\n-You can view information about users, groups, and resources that can access account information from an external account in Permissions Management.\n-\n-## Display information about users, groups, or tasks\n-\n-1. In Permissions Management, select the **Usage analytics** tab, and then, from the dropdown, select one of the following:\n-\n-   - **Users**\n-   - **Group**\n-   - **Active resources**\n-   - **Active tasks**\n-   - **Active resources**\n-   - **Serverless functions**\n-\n-1. To choose an account from your authorization system, select the lock icon in the left panel.\n-1. In the **Authorization systems** pane, select an account, then select **Apply**.\n-1. To choose a user, role, or group, select the person icon.\n-1. Select a user or group, then select **Apply**.\n-1. To choose an account from your authorization system, select it from the Authorization Systems menu.\n-1. In the user type filter, user, role, or group.\n-1. In the **Task** filter, select **All** or **High-risk tasks**, then select **Apply**.\n-1. To delete a task, select **Delete**, then select **Apply**.\n-\n-## Export information about users, groups, or tasks\n-\n-To export the data in comma-separated values (CSV) file format, select **Export** from the top-right hand corner of the table.\n-\n-## View users and roles\n-1. To view users and roles, select the lock icon, and then select the person icon to open the **Users** pane.\n-1. To view the **Role summary**, select the \"eye\" icon to the right of the role name.\n-\n-   The following details display:\n-   - **Policies**: A list of all the policies attached to the role.\n-   - **Trusted entities**: The identities from external accounts that can assume this role.\n-\n-1. To view all the identities from various accounts that can assume this role, select the down arrow to the left of the role name.\n-1. To view a graph of all the identities that can access the specified account and through which role(s), select the role name.\n-\n-   If Permissions Management is monitoring the external account, it lists specific identities from the accounts that can assume this role. Otherwise, it lists the identities declared in the **Trusted entity** section.\n-\n-   **Connecting roles**: Lists the following roles for each account:\n-      - *Direct roles* that are trusted by the account role.\n-      - *Intermediary roles* that aren't directly trusted by the account role but are assumable by identities through role-chaining.\n-\n-1. To view all the roles from that account that are used to access the specified account, select the down arrow to the left of the account name.\n-1. To view the trusted identities declared by the role, select the down arrow to the left of the role name.\n-\n-   The trusted identities for the role are listed only if the account is being monitored by Permissions Management.\n-\n-1. To view the role definition, select the \"eye\" icon to the right of the role name.\n-\n-   When you select the down arrow and expand details, a search box is displayed. Enter your criteria in this box to search for specific roles.\n-\n-   **Identities with access**: Lists the identities that come from external accounts:\n-      - To view all the identities from that account can access the specified account, select the down arrow to the left of the account name.\n-      - To view the **Role summary** for EC2 instances and Lambda functions, select the \"eye\" icon to the right of the identity name.\n-      - To view a graph of how the identity can access the specified account and through which role(s), select the identity name.\n-\n-1. The **Dashboard** tab displays the **Permissions Creep Index (PCI)** and **Identity findings** information about the account.\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-For more information about the **Permissions Creep Index (PCI)** and SCP information, see [View key statistics and data about your authorization system](ui-dashboard.md)."
  },

    "sha": "25c734cd05bd9cfda43e086805d3427a164ac725",
